urn:contentItem:5RX8-HCW1-DXH2-62WW-00000-00Cambridge Analytica harvested data from millions of unsuspecting Facebook users2018-03-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:30ZLexisNexisNBC NIGHTLY NEWS7:00 PM ESTNEWSDomestic031903cb.502Cambridge Analytica harvested data from millions of unsuspecting Facebook usersLester Holt, Jo Ling Kent

Facebook took a major hit on Wall Street today losing over forty billion dollars in market value after the revelations that Cambridge Analytica, a company tied to the Trump campaign, allegedly collected data from tens of millions of Facebook profiles, all in the run-up to the 2016 election.

LESTER HOLT (00:06:46): Facebook took a major hit on Wall Street today losing over forty billion dollars in market value after the revelations that Cambridge Analytica, a company tied to the Trump campaign, allegedly collected data from tens of millions of Facebook profiles, all in the run- up to the 2016 election. NBC business correspondent Jo Ling Kent has more on the fallout.

(Begin VT)

JO LING KENT (NBC News Business Correspondent) (00:07:09): Tonight, Facebook stock tanking, dropping nearly seven percent after allegations that data firm Cambridge Analytica secretly harvested the personal information of fifty million unsuspecting Facebook users.

CHRISTOPHER WYLIE (00:07:22): They are not just a social network. They are also a-- a-- an information battle space.

JO LING KENT (00:07:28): Whistleblower Christopher Wylie helped found Cambridge which later was brought on to help the Trump campaign. The firm hired by Jared Kushner who oversaw the digital operation and by Brad Parscale who`s now running the Trump 2020 reelection efforts.

CHRISTOPHER WYLIE (00:07:43): It`s really important that Americans understand what has happened with their data, their private information.

JO LING KENT (00:07:50): Starting in 2014, Cambridge Analytica funded a personality test on Facebook and paid people to take it, this allowed the company to gather personal information from participants` Facebook feeds. But what users didn`t know, the company was also collecting data about their Facebook friends. The alleged goal: influence the views of the American electorate. In hidden camera video from our British partner ITN Channel 4, a company executive, told a reporter posing as a perspective client about the company`s edge in politics.

MAN #1 (recording) (00:08:21): I wouldn`t have thought. So, no, we`ll bring some,

MAN #2 (recording) (00:08:21): It`s no good fighting an election campaign on the facts because actually it`s all about emotion.

JO LING KENT (00:08:29): Another executive brags about the lengths they would be willing to go for a client.

MAN #3 (recording) (00:08:33): Send some girls around to the candidate`s house. We have lots of history of things.

JO LING KENT (00:08:39): Tonight, Cambridge Analytica denies misusing Facebook data and says, "We entirely refute any allegation that Cambridge Analytica or any of its affiliates used entrapment, bribes, or so-called the honey-traps for any purpose whatsoever.." Facebook which also owns Instagram, banned Cambridge Analytica from its platform and hired a digital forensic firm to investigate saying, ".we remain committed to vigorously enforcing our policies to protect people`s information," amid new calls for more regulation of social media companies.

SCOTT GALLOWAY (NYU Stern School of Business Professor of Marketing) (00:09:12): We`re seeing the beginning of the breakup of big tech. Big tech has not been held at the same scrutiny as the rest of corporate America.

(End VT)

JO LING KENT (00:09:20): Privacy experts say users should be aware that every like, post, or photo can reveal private information by your location, your preferences, and your political leanings, and all of that could be used for targeting. Lester.

LESTER HOLT (00:09:33): All right. Jo Ling Kent, tonight. Thank you.

urn:contentItem:5VN3-BKW1-JCJ6-Y4G6-00000-00Cambridge Analytica, l'affaire qui a bouleversé le Web2019-03-15T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:30ZLexisNexisACTUALITÉS TECHTech & WebTech & WebCambridge Analytica, l'affaire qui a bouleversé le WebLucie Ronfautlronfaut@lefigaro.frElisa Braunebraun@lefigaro.fr

Il y a un an démarrait la pire crise de l'histoire de Facebook. Ce scandale a aussi chamboulé les relations entre les géants des technologies et le reste du monde.

C'est le 17 mars 2018 que tout a basculé. Il y a un an, deux médias, le New York Times et le London's Observer(le magazine du journal britannique The Guardian), révélaient l'exploitation frauduleuse de données d'utilisateursFacebook par une société britannique, au profit de la campagne de Donald Trump et de celle pour le Brexit, en Grande-Bretagne. Au total, ce sont 87 millions de personnes dont les informations personnelles ont été siphonnées sans leur consentement.

Ce scandale est le point de départ de la pire crise de l'histoire de Facebook, qui perdure aujourd'hui. Mais, il a aussi provoqué un électrochoc dans le monde, politiques et citoyens prenant conscience de l'ampleur du pouvoir des géants des nouvelles technologies dans nos vies et nos démocraties. En 2012, quand Barack Obama avait utilisé des données issues des réseaux sociaux pour gagner la présidentielle, le monde avait salué les méthodes d'un président novateur. Quatre ans plus tard, les méthodes de Cambridge Analytica ont au contraire jeté un froid dans la communauté internationale.

Hasard du calendrier, le scandale est tombé deux mois avant l'entrée en vigueur d'un de ces textes de spécialistes, le Règlement général sur la protection des données personnelles (RGPD). Il a imposé ce texte européen comme un standard nécessaire aux yeux de la communauté internationale. Aux États-Unis, il a d'abord inspiré la Californie, qui a adopté en juin 2018 sa propre loi en matière de vie privée, le California Consumer Privacy Act (CCPA). Dans ce même intervalle, plusieurs membres du Congrès ont poussé à leur tour l'idée de créer un RGPD à l'échelle fédérale. L'idée est paradoxalement soutenue par les géants du Web, qui souhaitent une version plus souple que la loi californienne au niveau fédéral mais aussi éviter un patchwork de législation entre cinquante et un États. Ailleurs dans le monde, l'Inde, le Canada ou encore le Japon veulent eux aussi leur RGPD.

Une menace économique

Pour le moment, l'affaire Cambridge Analytica n'a pas vraiment eu de conséquences sur les finances de Facebook. En 2018, le chiffre d'affaires total de l'entreprise a atteint 55,8 milliards de dollars, en hausse de 37 % sur un an, et son bénéfice s'est établi à 22,1 milliards de dollars. Néanmoins, Mark Zuckerberg a prévenu ses actionnaires que les profits de sa société risquaient d'être réduits en raison de sanctions à prévoir courant 2019, notamment de la Federal Trade Commission, qui veille aux droits des consommateurs aux États-Unis. L'institution devrait prochainement prononcer une amende de plusieurs milliards de dollars contre le géant. En termes d'organisation, Facebook a aussi perdu une dizaine de dirigeants en un an. Jeudi, c'est Chris Cox, numéro trois de l'entreprise, qui a pris la porte.

» LIRE AUSSI - Facebook perd l'un de ses dirigeants historiques

Encore plus inquiétante, une menace inédite plane sur Facebook et les autres géants des technologies: celle du démantèlement. Aux États-Unis, des élus en ont même fait un axe central de leur programme électoral pour la prochaine élection présidentielle de 2020, à l'image de la candidate à l'investiture démocrate Elizabeth Warren. Celle-ci soutient l'interdiction des fusions entre Amazon et la chaîne de distribution d'alimentation bio Whole Foods, ou encore de Facebook, WhatsApp et Instagram. Elle n'est d'ailleurs pas la seule à prôner la régulation fédérale du secteur. Côté républicain, des personnalités politiques conservatrices comme Ted Cruz appellent également au démantèlement de ce qu'elles appellent les «big tech».

Un «gangster du numérique». Voilà le verdict du Parlement britannique, rendu en février, à la suite d'une longue enquête sur les efforts de Facebook pour lutter contre la désinformation en ligne. Car Cambridge Analytica n'était que le début des ennuis pour le réseau social: l'affaire a permis aux détracteurs de Facebook de l'attaquer sur divers sujets qui menaçaient depuis longtemps l'entreprise, poussés par un fort sentiment anti-Gafa des politiques et des citoyens. Sur le respect de la vie privée, la fiscalité, la désinformation en ligne, la modération, l'anticoncurrence... En Europe et dans le monde, les projets de loi se multiplient, contraignant Facebook mais aussi les autres géants du Web dans leurs activités. À l'inverse, certaines entreprises ont profité de cette période trouble pour faire du respect de la vie privée un véritable enjeu marketing. C'est notamment le cas d'Apple, dont le PDG, Tim Cook, a régulièrement attaqué Mark Zuckerberg tout au long de l'année.

Celle-ci soutient l'interdiction des fusions entre Amazon et la chaîne de distribution d'alimentation bio Whole Foods, ou encore de Facebook, WhatsApp et Instagram. Elle n'est d'ailleurs pas la seule à prôner la régulation fédérale du secteur. Côté républicain, des personnalités politiques conservatrices comme Ted Cruz appellent également au démantèlement de ce qu'elles appellent les « big tech ».

Une image écornée

Un « gangster du numérique ». Voilà le verdict du Parlement britannique, rendu en février, à la suite d'une longue enquête sur les efforts de Facebook pour lutter contre la désinformation en ligne. Car Cambridge Analytica n'était que le début des ennuis pour le réseau social : l'affaire a permis aux détracteurs de Facebook de l'attaquer sur divers sujets qui menaçaient depuis longtemps l'entreprise, poussés par un fort sentiment anti-Gafa des politiques et des citoyens. Sur le respect de la vie privée, la fiscalité, la désinformation en ligne, la modération, l'anticoncurrence... En Europe et dans le monde, les projets de loi se multiplient, contraignant Facebook mais aussi les autres géants du Web dans leurs activités. À l'inverse, certaines entreprises ont profité de cette période trouble pour faire du respect de la vie privée un véritable enjeu marketing. C'est notamment le cas d'Apple, dont le PDG, Tim Cook, a régulièrement attaqué Mark Zuckerberg tout au long de l'année.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5RXR-1WC1-DXSP-91XC-00000-00Cambridge Analytica revelations put pressure on all large tech firms2018-03-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:30ZLexisNexisCambridge Analytica revelations put pressure on all large tech firmsMkitchen

Professor André Spicer, Cass Business School, comments on Cambridge Analytica and questions what the costs will be to big tech firms?

Recent revelations about Cambridge Analytica will put pressure on not just Facebook, but many large tech companies. They will be forced to expand their compliance, privacy and social responsibility functions. Big tech firms are going from being darlings to being devils in the public imagination.

Big tech firms have a Californian mindset: they assume that people will generally do the right thing but this is being challenged. Now, they're having to stop focusing on the sunny side of human behaviour and start recognising the more sinister side. They are scrambling to keep up by developing techniques for hunting down fake news, harmful content and online bullying.

Tech firms are now going to be under pressure to show the thousands of businesses who are plugged into their platform that they are complying with their policies. This could mean a rapid expansion of compliance bureaucracy. For the company, this is likely to mean more cost. For users, more terms and conditions they don't understand.

The really big issue is if regulators start questioning the business model of tech firms. Currently, consumers give away their data in exchange for free services, but what if regulators start putting a price on people's data? According to one estimate, each user is worth about USD45 to Google a year, but the firm provides them with USD37 worth of service. Citizens and regulators might start asking what is happening to the other USD7? offFlag:

This could mean a rapid expansion of compliance bureaucracy. For the company, this is likely to mean more cost. For users, more terms and conditions they don't understand.

The really big issue is if regulators start questioning the business model of tech firms. Currently, consumers give away their data in exchange for free services, but what if regulators start putting a price on people's data? According to one estimate, each user is worth about USD45 to Google a year, but the firm provides them with USD37 worth of service. Citizens and regulators might start asking what is happening to the other USD7? offFlag:

urn:contentItem:5866-K6B1-JCW9-20CN-00000-00Cambridge Analytica ruse lets Facebook off the hook2018-03-31T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:30ZLexisNexisCambridge Analytica ruse lets Facebook off the hookColin Murphy

Liberals are crying foul because Trump beat them with the social media tactics pioneered by Obama

Donald Trump won the presidency of the United States thanks to the deployment of a new and dangerous covert technology of voter persuasion built on Facebook data and developed by a rogue political consultancy called Cambridge Analytica; their actions, and this new technology, threaten the fabric of democracy itself.

This is the terrifying story that has dominated the international news for the past fortnight. The problem is that it’s not necessarily true. A story that is largely about the use of smoke and mirrors in elections is itself surrounded by smoke and mirrors. Amid the confusion, we may lose sight of the real problem.

Cambridge Analytica claimed to have developed an unprecedented dataset on American voters which, allied with personality-profiling tools, allowed it to “microtarget” political messaging in a way that would redefine political campaigning. Chris Wylie, the company’s former research director, now a whistleblower, has said this dataset was built on the back of data obtained from Facebook, and that similar techniques were used by a related company in the Brexit referendum. (Cambridge Analytica has rejected the various allegations.)

But the evidence that any of this had a marked impact is thin. The Brexit campaign was brilliantly and unscrupulously targeted, but not by Cambridge Analytica, and not covertly.

The head of the Vote Leave campaign, Dominic Cummings, told the Spectator that the campaign’s own micro-level analysis found that the most effective message with all groups was, “Let’s give our NHS the £350 million the EU takes every week”.

Cambridge Analytica worked for Ted Cruz in the Republican primary: James Nix boasted that they took Cruz from being a nobody to coming second; Cruz spokesman Rick Tyler told BBC Newsnight that Cambridge Analytica gave the campaign “no strategic advantage at all . . . In the end, it was just bullshit”.

Cambridge Analytica had said they would apply this methodology to the Trump campaign, but have since said that they they were hired too late to do so.

The Trump campaign was brilliantly and unscrupulously targeted, but by Steve Bannon, not Cambridge Analytica. It was Bannon who harnessed the Trump campaign “to a single political view: that the path to victory was an economic and cultural message to the white working class in Florida, Ohio, Michigan and Pennsylvania”, wrote Michael Wolff, in Fire and Fury: Inside the Trump White House.

Or more simply: “Here’s what won it for Trump,” said Bannon recently, in response to the Cambridge Analytica story: “economic nationalism” and “plain language”. The harsh truth for liberals is that, like Obama before him, Trump told a better story.

That’s not all that Trump and Obama have in common. It was the Obama 2012 campaign that pioneered online micro-targetting; but this tended to be reported in eulogistic tech-utopian terms, rather than the Orwellian ones that have dominated this story.

So Trump is a distraction, as ever. Cambridge Analytica didn’t need to acquire Facebook data via a third-party app; the Trump campaign didn’t need to hire Cambridge Analytica to do micro-targeting. They could have just paid Facebook to do it for them.

The threat to democracy exists. Cambridge Analytica has brought this threat to mainstream attention in a way that satisfies the liberal narrative of the illegitimacy of Donald Trump; strip away that cladding and what remains is a more insidious, less dramatic story than the idea of rogue agents (Cambridge Analytica; the Russians) robbing elections. This threat is the cumulative impact of our growing addiction to social media and technology, through which we share ever more data, for which ever more ways to monetise it are found.

These trends have made Facebook and Alphabet (the parent company of Google) the third and seventh most valuable companies in the world. They have an effective duopoly of the digital advertising market and have cannibalised the print news industry. They know more about people and society than any institution, ever.

Keeping up is going to stretch law-makers and regulators to their limits. Transparency of political advertising online, as mandated in the Honest Ads Act currently before the US Congress, and tighter data privacy laws and regulation, are necessary measures, but marginal. More radical measures are needed.

One option is the kind of trust-busting that has a long history in the US (Standard Oil was broken up in 1911, AT&T in 1982; Microsoft was due to be broken up in 2001 but appealed, and the Department of Justice then settled). Another would be a sea-change in data laws that would place radical restrictions on what can be kept or harvested. Apple manages vast amounts of user data in its iCloud service; it charges for the service instead of harvesting the data for ad targeting.

A more modest initiative that could have far-reaching effects would be simply to recognise the reality that Facebook and most social media companies are now first and foremost publishers, rather than tech companies. This would change the incentive structure for Facebook, incentivising it to block content which could be potentially harmful, as opposed to the status quo, where it has a financial incentive to allow any content that attracts eyeballs, and therefore advertising.

But the Achilles’ heel of Facebook, and its social media peers, lies in its very success. The compulsive checking of your phone for notifications and updates may be normal, but it is not healthy. These devices – hardware and software – are addictive, and that addiction is damaging, most obviously to children. As we come to understand this more, my hunch is that what is now normal will come to be seen, in retrospect, as dysfunctional. Big Tech may outrun the legislators on competition law, on data privacy, on content monitoring, on regulation; but eventually, the public health argument is going to overtake it.

urn:contentItem:5RY8-K3C1-JCJY-G3CP-00000-00Cambridge Analytica scandal: Mark Zuckerberg may regret running Facebook like a cult;The data-harvesting scandal is sending Facebook shares tumbling and its staff to the exit2018-03-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:30ZLexisNexisNEWS REVIEWVersion:1Cambridge Analytica scandal: Mark Zuckerberg may regret running Facebook like a cultThe data-harvesting scandal is sending Facebook shares tumbling and its staff to the exitBryan Appleyard and Danny Fortson

In the midst of his great apology interview tour last week, the Facebook boss Mark Zuckerberg said something crucial but largely unnoticed. "I used to think," he told CNN, "that the most important thing to me by far was my having the greatest positive impact across the world that I can. Now I really just care about building something that my girls are going to grow up and be proud of me for."

It may sound sweet, but bringing in the daughters was a carefully calculated attempt to deal with the Zuck's most awkward public relations problem: people don't like him. Take Senator Dick Durbin, when he was asked whether Zuckerberg should turn up in Washington to face questions. "Wouldn't it be great," he said, sarcasm rising off him like steam, "for him to show up like most Americans do when asked to testify as to the practices of his company?"

In all the coverage of the way Cambridge Analytica "harvested" Facebook's data on 50m of its users, the most consistent theme was: Zuck's a creepy geek who doesn't get it. Even The Economist stooped to a sarcastic sneer when suggesting he might see an 80% drop in his company's earnings when the regulators moved in: "How would you like that, Mr Zuckerberg?"

This wave of distaste has been brought about by the revelations about Cambridge Analytica, which, two weeks ago, was thought to be the mysterious master of the big data universe. An academic created a Facebook questionnaire app that lured 270,000 people into giving it access to their data. These people had 50m Facebook friends who unwittingly yielded up their data too. Cambridge Analytica swooped on this trove. They were then exposed as a bunch of twerps by undercover Channel 4 reporters in an exposé that engulfed Facebook.

None of which should matter for a $500bn company that controls the eyeballs of more than a quarter of the world's population. But it does because, financially and operationally, Zuckerberg is Facebook. "Facebook is Mark, and Mark is Facebook," said the pollster Tavis McGinn. "Mark has 60% voting rights . . . So you have one individual, 33 years old, who has basically full control of the experience of 2bn people around the world."

McGinn was brought in by Facebook last year to "track the public perception of Mark Zuckerberg", a tricky job that also included tracking the company's chief operating officer, Sheryl Sandberg, 48. Sandberg, like Zuckerberg, was mysteriously absent for the days after the scandal broke but emerged on Thursday. "We definitely didn't realise the gravity of these issues," she told CNBC, a startling admission given the scale of the dumped data. Staff call his office "the Aquarium" and hers "Only Good News". The two of them tried to be lovable by issuing an end-of-year video in 2016, a wincingly awful exchange of sweet corporate nothings. McGinn left, contractually unable to disclose his results.

He did, however, set up Honest Data, a polling company that found that 27% of people thought Facebook was having a negative impact on the world. It came out worst among the big tech companies. Indeed only one company on his questionnaire was seen more unfavourably, the tobacco firm Marlboro.

Reputationally, Zuckerberg has crashed from the heavens. He was an internet god. Look at the books that were written about him - Think Like Zuck, Fifty Inspirational Life Lessons to Learn from Mark Zuckerberg, The Boy Billionaire and even Mark Zuckerberg, Vampire Slayer. (The film about him, The Social Network, was perhaps a more realistic portrayal.) His head turned by such adulation, is he likely to learn anything from these polls or from the Cambridge Analytica scandal? Probably not. He is, you see, a 33-year-old teenager with issues.

Every January, for example, he likes to announce his personal challenges for the coming year. These have included wearing ties, learning Mandarin, reading 25 books, running 365 miles. Last year it was visiting the 30 US states he had never been to. Like the appointment of McGinn, this was generally seen as part of a test run for the presidency - a risible ambition then; now even more so.

In 2011 his challenge was to eat meat only from animals he had personally killed. This proved a death sentence for an unfortunate bison whose head was used to decorate the Facebook offices.

This isn't the brilliant, narcissistic capering of Steve Jobs, the abrupt, nerdy genius of Bill Gates or the cold, corporate calculation of Google; it's either teen pranks or fantastically clumsy attempts to make Facebook look cool.

This year's challenge immediately came back to bite him where it hurts - it was to "fix Facebook".

"If we're successful this year," he wrote, "we'll end 2018 on a much better trajectory." Okaaaay.

The previous scandal - about Russia's use of Facebook in its meddling with the 2016 election - was at first brushed aside by Zuckerberg. His reaction to this latest scandal was generally agreed to be inadequate. It was also several days too late.

This was, it has been reported, because of a disagreement at the top of the company about what to do. One side wanted to do nothing; the other wanted to do a lot - to, in fact, fix Facebook. This argument is the heart of the matter.

Tech companies like to have grand mission statements: Facebook's was "to make the world more open and connected". Mission statements, however, never survive first contact with Wall Street. The brilliant programmer who created Facebook in his Harvard dorm had to become the businessman who would make it pay. And, because of the peculiar and deeply flawed structure of the internet, the only way to do that was advertising. Both Google and Facebook are advertising companies, and they form a dangerous duopoly that must surely, one day, be broken up.

As everybody knows, Facebook employs users' data to drive its advertising business. But Facebook uses it far more ruthlessly than people realise, notably combining internal profile material with external tracking in a system called Custom Audiences. Once you've got it all working, this is easy money.

But it all depends on Zuckerberg's mantra: "We are an open platform." To survive in its present form, Facebook has to minimise its responsibility for content. It needs to be like a content-neutral phone company, not a content- responsible publishing company. The execs who wanted to downplay the reaction last week did so because they knew that every discussion of content increases the threat to their business plan.

"They have," said Zuckerberg's former mentor Roger McNamee last week, "a deep philosophical belief that they are a platform, not a media company." He also made it clear this was an existential crisis for the company: "They're so far off track now, I don't know how they get back."

The company has shot itself in the foot by, falteringly, toying with the idea that it is a news service. This would make it a publishing company and therefore subject to the same regulation as newspapers or TV channels. Anyway, going to Facebook for news is like going to B&Q for your milk: a category error.

Every discussion about Facebook is now about content. The "open platform" idea has succumbed to what social scientists call the "tragedy of the commons" - any shared resource will be exploited by self-interested users. These users are those such as Russia and Cambridge Analytica, but also politicians who, like Donald Trump, can exploit the advertising system. Facebook's algorithms do not just sell ad space to the highest bidder; they prioritise ads that grab attention, which makes a supposedly neutral platform an extremism-generating machine.

Content talk has driven Zuckerberg to a cliff edge, but does he know this? Truth-tellers such as McGinn and McNamee have left and, as executives' pay is partly shares-based, last week's dive in the share price may prove ominous for recruitment and keeping the best staff happy. Some are even leaving because they have acquired a conscience.

After the Russia-Trump-Facebook rumpus of the 2016 election, McNamee emailed Sandberg and Zuckerberg: "I am really sad about Facebook. I got involved with the company more than a decade ago and have taken great pride and joy in the company's success . . . until the past few months. Now I am disappointed. I am embarrassed. I am ashamed."

Alex Stamos, chief security officer, is now leaving seemingly because he was out of step with other executives when he said there should be more disclosure about Russian interference. In addition, over its 14-year life Facebook has made many workers very rich. They have left to live their lives or start their own companies. Zuckerberg may or may not be lonely, but he is certainly isolated.

His further problem is very personal. It is that Facebook is no longer a monolithic cult built around the character of its co-founder and his mission statement.

Antonio Garcia Martinez, a self- described heartbroken idealist, was a senior advertising executive at Facebook. "You actually," he said, "have leaks coming out of Facebook now, which is unprecedented. Everyone in Silicon Valley would agree that, before the [2016] election, Facebook was famously difficult to penetrate. Nobody would talk."

The internet was designed, idealistically, to be a free information resource for everybody. But this created a funding vacuum that has been filled by advertising. If somebody had built a payments system - for example, a penny for every email - this monopolistic chaos of tragically ruined commons might never have happened. But we are where we are, and the Zuck is where he is, teetering and hoping his daughters will be proud.@bryanappleyardFacebook's 'gaping wound of data': go to thesundaytimes.co.uk/dannyinthevalley to listen to series two of our podcast

urn:contentItem:5S6J-F301-JBHT-D3R7-00000-00Cambridge Analytica scandal: Silicon Valley may get its comeuppance2018-04-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:30ZLexisNexisPg. 12Cambridge Analytica scandal: Silicon Valley may get its comeuppanceFareed ZakariaSalt Lake CityFULL TEXT

We might look back on 2017 as the last moment of unbridled faith and optimism in the technology industry. The revelations about Cambridge Analytica's use of Facebook data - mining more than 50 million users' personal information - came at a time when people were already considering appropriate ways to curb the handful of powerful tech companies that dominate not just the American economy but, increasingly, American life.

As the information revolution took off in the 1990s, we all got caught up in the excitement of the age, the novelty of the products and their transformative power. We were dazzled by the wealth created by nebbishy 25-year-olds, who themselves became instant billionaires - the ultimate revenge of the nerds. And in the midst of all this, as America was transitioning into a digital economy, we neglected to ask: "What is the role for government here?"

The image of technology companies springing forth from unfettered free markets was never quite accurate. Today's digital economy rests on three major technologies: the computer chip, the Internet and GPS. All three owe their existence in large part to the federal government. The latter two were, of course, developed from scratch, owned and run by the government until they were opened up to the private sector. Most people don't realize that GPS - the global positioning system of satellites and control centers that is so crucial to the modern economy - is, even now, owned by the U.S. government and operated by the Air Force.

And yet, as these revolutionary technologies created new industries, destroyed others and reshaped communities and cities, we simply assumed that this was the way of the world and that nothing could be done to affect it. That would be socialist-style interference with the free market.

But the result does not seem one that a libertarian would celebrate. We now have a tech economy dominated by just a few mammoth companies that effectively create a barrier to entry for newcomers. In Silicon Valley today, new startups don't even pretend that they will ever grow to become independent companies. Their business plan is to be acquired by Google, Face-book, Amazon, Microsoft or Apple. The situation looks more like an oligopoly than a free market. In fact, through the age of big tech, the number of new business startups has been declining.

The other noticeable consequence has been the erosion of privacy, highlighted by the Cambridge Analytica/Facebook scandal. Because technology companies now deal with billions of consumers, any individual is a speck, a tiny data point. And since, for most technology companies, the individual consumer is also a product, whose information is sold to others for a profit, he or she is doubly disempowered. The technology companies would surely respond that they have democratized information, created products of extraordinary power and potential, and transformed life for the better. All this is true. So, did previous technologies like the telephone, the automobile, antibiotics and electricity. But precisely because of their power and transformational impact, it was necessary for the government to play some role in protecting individuals and restraining the huge new winners in the economy.

Change is likely to come from two directions. Regulatory action in the West will provide protections for the individual to better control his or her data. The European Union has established rules, which will come into effect on May 25, that will make it much easier for individuals to know how their data is being used and to limit that use. It is likely that the U.S. will follow suit.

The second direction is even more intriguing and comes from the East. Until recently, as Indian entrepreneur Nandan Nilekani pointed out to me, there were just a handful of digital platforms with more than 1 billion users, all run by companies in the United States or China such as Google, Facebook and Tencent. But now, India has its own billion-person digital platform: the extraordinary "Aadhaar" biometric ID system, which now includes almost all of the nation's 1.3 billion citizens (and whose creation Nilekani oversaw). It is the only of these massive platforms that is publicly owned. That means it does not need to make money off user data. It's possible to imagine that in India, it will become normal to think of data as personal property that individuals can keep or rent or sell as they wish in a very open and democratic free market. India might well become the global innovator for individuals' data rights.

Add innovations in blockchain technology and we are likely to see more challenges to the current gatekeepers of the Internet in the near future.

Whether from East or West, top down or bottom up, change is coming to transform the world of technology. Properly handled, it can produce freer markets and greater individual empowerment.

Fareed Zakaria's email address is comments@fareedzakaria.com

urn:contentItem:5RXG-W1T1-F021-64VR-00000-00Cambridge Analytica sets quandary for right: hate Facebook, love Trump;The scandal of the data mining company produced complicated feelings on the right as hatred of big tech companies vied with sensitivity about Trump's victoryFacebook's Mark Zuckerberg finally addresses Cambridge Analytica scandal2018-03-21T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:30ZLexisNexisUS NEWSVersion:3Cambridge Analytica sets quandary for right: hate Facebook, love TrumpThe scandal of the data mining company produced complicated feelings on the right as hatred of big tech companies vied with sensitivity about Trump's victoryFacebook's Mark Zuckerberg finally addresses Cambridge Analytica scandalJason Wilson

News of the Cambridge Analytica scandal, which may have helped elect Donald Trump, has awakened complicated feelings in rightwing media.

On the one hand, it plays into some conservatives' increasing hostility to big tech firms, and social media companies in particular. Seeing Facebook in trouble has allowed many to vent some righteous fury.

On the other, the story's implicit suggestion that Trump's victory was less than legitimate has led others to insist either that the problem of social media manipulation does not exist, or that Democrats are even worse.

To understand the first response, remember that Facebook, Twitter and Google have recently rejigged their algorithms or tightened their rules in order to address a perceived extremism problem.

But this has led to claims that the companies have skewed their platforms to penalize conservative speech. It's also led some on the conservative and radical right to pursue legal action against Twitter, YouTube and others on free speech grounds.

Related: The Cambridge Analytica saga is a scandal of Facebook's own making | John Harris

So no surprise that on the Drudge Report, the links page at the center of the conservative internet, there has been a gleeful curation of stories about Facebook's troubles, with taunting link texts like "Facebook Freakout", "Where's Zuckerberg", and "Busy Selling Shares".

Others have taken the opportunity to directly link the story to the perceived "viewpoint discrimination" against conservatives.

On Gateway Pundit, in characteristic dot-point prose, Jim Hoft alleged that Facebook itself is biased against conservative viewpoints. He argued that Donald Trump and conservative sites have been targeted by algorithm changes, and have lost traffic, while liberal politicians have suffered no such hit. He wrapped it up with an increasingly common question among conservatives: "isn't about time lawmakers take action to prevent Facebook from shutting down conservative voices?"

On RedState, Seton Motley expanded the discussion to include the other three members of tech's "big four": Google, Amazon and Twitter. The fact that those companies "loathe conservatives and conservatism", he claimed, was "the world's worst kept secret". Their power, he said, enabled them to "warp or silence our political communications". He finished with some hand-wringing about how conservatives' suspicion of regulation means that it's difficult for them to imagine what to do about it.

The second kind of response to the story involves those who, above all, are concerned that the Facebook caper will be folded into the broader narrative of Russian collusion.

Those seeking to protect Trump at all costs were thrown a lifeline late on Monday. A former Obama campaign staffer, Carol Davidsen, put out a number of tweets seeming to indicate that in 2012, their organization had also been given broad access to Facebook user data. "Facebook was surprised we were able to suck out the whole social graph," she wrote, "but they didn't stop us."

For "alt-right" blogger and author, Vox Day, this was enough to confirm that "Facebook is in SERIOUS trouble", and he did a back-of-the-envelope sum leading to the conclusion that the company may owe "$200bn in potential FTC fines".

Another part of Davidsen's remarks, where she said that Facebook was "on our side", became the basis of headlines from RT to ZeroHedge, and dutifully amplified by the likes of   Infowars.

The story was also covered by Breitbart, where schadenfreude led to a possibly unprecedented step: a straight and sympathetic   rewrite of a Guardian column.

Others tried to wave the whole thing away.

In the New York Times, Ross Douthat claimed it was television, not social media, that was crucial in Trump's election.

On his radio show, Rush Limbaugh insisted that there was nothing to see. Facebook collects a lot of data, he argued, and "Cambridge analytics [sic] is like any other outfit that found a way to access it, and it's not illegal." Then, with trademark bluster, he pointed the finger of blame at a familiar party.

"Google, the kings of data collection, Google, the kings of harvesting everybody's personal data to use in advertising and who knows whatever else, practically had a White House relationship with Barack Hussein O," said Limbaugh.

More than a year since he left office, in times of trouble, conservatives are still using Obama as their most reliable punching bag.

urn:contentItem:5SPX-3891-F04Y-T2S4-00000-00Cambridge Analytica used our secrets for profit the same data could be used for public good2018-07-04T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:30ZLexisNexisCambridge Analytica used our secrets for profit the same data could be used for public good

Link to Image

Link to Story

Ever since it was revealed that Cambridge Analytica had taken data from 87m users via a Facebook app that exploited the social media site's privacy settings, it has been suggested that anything from Donald Trump's election in the US to the European Union referendum result in the UK could have been the result of the persuasive power of targeted advertisements based on voter preferences. But Aleksandr Kogan, the University of Cambridge researcher whose data-collecting app formed the basis for Cambridge Analytica's subsequent work for various political groups, appeared to pour cold water on this idea when speaking to a US Senate committee . 'The data is entirely ineffective,' he said. 'If the goal of Cambridge Analytica was to show personalised advertisements on Facebook, then what they did was stupid.' Even if the boasts by former Cambridge Analytica CEO Alexander Nix and the statements of whistleblower Christopher Wylie of the company's influence are overblown as Kogan claims, the firm nevertheless hit on something with its approach of harvesting data in order to influence voter behaviour.

Before that approach becomes commonplace, we should survey the whole moral panic around the scandal and see what lessons can be learnt. Use and abuse of data The first issue is our misunderstanding of consent. Kogan's data-scrape may have been unethical, but he didn't steal the data from those that used the app - they gave it willingly. When you use a social media platform you, by definition, are publishing your private life. More so, you effectively sell your private life on an open market through giving your consent for it to be monetised by that platform. Following admissions by Facebook chief operating officer Sheryl Sandberg, we now know that 'online privacy' settings exist only as a means to allow Facebook users to believe they have a consumer's right to privacy, when in fact they are not the consumer, but the product itself. If privatisation is a process of transferring ownership from the public to the private realm, this means privacy itself has been privatised. You publish your data, making it public, so that private companies can capitalise on what this data says about you by selling you things. This leads to a paradoxical situation I call neoprivacy, following neoliberalism's similar disregard for and exploitation of the private individual. In a neoprivate world privacy exists to be exploited financially. The neoprivate individual both values their personal life so much that they publish it, yet is so neglectful of their privacy that, well, they publish it. Cambridge Analytica's stroke of genius was to combine two different kinds of datasets, let's call them deep and broad. The deep psychometric tests of a small sample (from Kogan's app) were combined with the broad online behaviour of a massive sample. With this they claimed they could predict people's behaviour simply by their actions on Facebook . The firm sold this to political campaigns and lobbyists as their ' secret weapon '. This model shows a real understanding of social media by grounding it on people's actions on Facebook - what they click on, read, and like - rather than their expressed statements. It's what you do that matters , not what you say. Putting information up for only commercial interests is a wasted opportunity. pixinoo/Shutterstock Democratic data dividend I think this data-driven approach offers a democratic opportunity. Typically deep, expert research generates the evidence that informs policies. But data-driven governance appears increasingly disassociated from ordinary lives, with voters preferring crowd-pleasing factoids when it comes to major decisions. Indeed, suspicion of experts may even be a contributing factor in the rise of what could be called demagogcracy and fake news . In contrast, broad data is generated by people based on what they choose to do, not what an expert has asked them, or prompted them, to say. Neoprivate individuals feel a sense of ownership and investment when they share something on Facebook or Instagram. If anything online needs to be harvested, it is this sense of communal, social engagement. Yet our primal need for social engagement is both stymied by expert policy wonks with no grip of the grassroots, and monetised by the big platforms with no interest in civic society. Evidence-based governance was instigated under former prime minister, Tony Blair, that was supposed to be a panacea for the uncertainties of political decision making. It has failed. In contrast, the activity-based influence of broad data is a political model that has been shown in the hands of Trump to be frighteningly effective. If we are to fix democracies then future leaders should engage with both - albeit more transparently than Cambridge Analytica did. One final lesson: if we live in a neoprivate world, why couldn't we monetise our own lives just as the big tech companies have? If Facebook knows enough about me to advise me on what sort of shelf brackets I need, why couldn't this same level of insight be applied to more important, more technical, complex political decisions that need to be made by citizens, for their benefit? If Cambridge Analytica can develop algorithms that are good predictors of our behaviour, shouldn't that information be used to influence policy? Why shouldn't politicians harvest it for the greater good rather than personal gain? Many biopolitical theorists define our current age as that of power through regulatory surveillance ; it is time that neoliberal democracies transitioned to power through participatory enhancement. Two worlds remain an absolute mystery: Facebook's algorithms and why we vote the way we do. Place both those secrets in the public realm rather than in the hands of the highest bidder, and maybe democracy can develop its own app and fix itself. Now that's what I call neoliberalism. urn:contentItem:5YBH-CM11-DXKP-J017-00000-00Cambridge Analytica whistleblower: We should be scared about what we're going to see in this year's elections;Brittany Kaiser talks about the ways voters can be manipulated - and the corruption of elections.2020-03-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:32:30ZLexisNexisCambridge Analytica whistleblower: We should be scared about what we're going to see in this year's electionsBrittany Kaiser talks about the ways voters can be manipulated - and the corruption of elections.KK Ottesen

Brittany Kaiser is a data rights activist and whistleblower of Cambridge Analytica, the political consulting firm that harvested the data of 87 million Facebook users and did work for the 2016 Trump campaign. She is the author of "Targeted: The Cambridge Analytica Whistleblower's Inside Story of How Big Data, Trump, and Facebook Broke Democracy and How It Can Happen Again" and is a subject of the documentary film "The Great Hack."

When you were younger, you were an Obama supporter, you were interested in human rights advocacy. Can you talk about ending up at Cambridge Analytica and some of the decision points or rationalizations that kept you there for three-plus years?

I always assumed I would work in diplomacy or as a human rights lawyer and was working towards that. That's how I eventually ended up in Cambridge Analytica in the first place. Because I ended up doing my PhD in preventive diplomacy, looking into how people would be able to have enough real-time data to intervene in situations before they became violent. Specifically, looking into how you could prevent crimes against humanity and war crimes. [Former Cambridge Analytica CEO] Alexander Nix shared what they were doing for NATO and our allied militaries, which was to identify individuals vulnerable to be recruited into ISIS - young people in the United Kingdom either being recruited or possibly being sent messaging to encourage them to sneak into Syria. And to teach the digital teams of allied militaries to convince those kids to stay at home. I thought: This is amazing. That's what I want to learn how to do. So I'll take a consultancy and see where it goes.

I learned a lot more about data than I bargained for, obviously. I definitely started to quickly see the dark side of politics. Over the first year and a half I was there, we're in the middle of the Brexit campaign. And I'm starting to see a campaign that we're not running hands-on but did data work for in the beginning turn into something incredibly divisive. And then we get into the Trump campaign and various other conservative groups, advocacy organizations, that Cambridge was working for. You start to see projects specifically targeting neurotic people with messaging that shows their house getting broken into and saying, you know, A gun, it's not just a right. It's an insurance policy. That's where it starts to get quite creepy.

So what's your reaction?

I guess I kept telling myself: You're not running those campaigns. You're doing other things - and these people aren't going to win anyway. So it must be okay, right? It was only really after the Trump campaign when I had a two-day-long debrief presentation from my colleagues that ran the Trump campaign and the Trump super PAC when I really saw, for the first time, things that really disturbed me.

Can you give an example?

The chart that the Trump campaign had used to categorize different audience groups. On one axis, it's how likely you are to vote. The other axis is how much of a supporter you are of Trump or Hillary. And they have different audience groups for different strategies, but one of them is called "deterrents." These are the people that are definitely Hillary voters if they are going to vote. There's no way you can get them to vote for Donald Trump. But you could possibly get them not to vote at all.

Voter suppression.

Exactly. Blatantly. So then they showed us different groups within that group and how they message those people. For instance, conservative women, in order to turn them off, they made this video called "She Can't Run Her House." That advertisement was all about how Michelle Obama, who actually, at the time, was talking about her and Barack taking care of Sasha and Malia during the campaign, said, "If you can't run your own house, you can't run the White House. I'm going to take care of my family first." But it was taken out of context and spliced with all of these things about Bill and Monica Lewinsky and saying Hillary Clinton was an unreliable woman because she had stayed with her cheating husband. And that was sent to women who were modeled to care about conservative values as their top political issue.

And that's where I said, I won't work for this company in America anymore. If you let me leave the country and start my own office, I'll stay. Because my father had had brain surgery, and it was quite obvious he was never going to work again, and no one else in my family had any money to pay any bills. So there was no way I was quitting my job over this. I just had to figure out a way to live with it. And I moved to Mexico to start my own office, so then I could work for people I wanted to work for and build something that was totally separate. That's the way that I justified it to myself.

You've said, "Big data, Trump and Facebook have broken our democracy." How do you feel about having been part of that?

Well, it's still disturbing every time I look back on it, how far everything went. You know, I started out in a place - the Obama campaign - where we were not allowed to do negative messaging, and ended up in a place that enhanced negative messaging to the point where, in my opinion, it should be considered criminal. But the way that I have dealt with it is to do everything I can to stop this from happening now. Because, unfortunately, we're even worse off than in 2016. You know, there's now hundreds of Cambridge Analyticas, not one.

And we now have Facebook deciding they're no longer going to moderate political content and that politicians won't even be held to community standards. They basically refuse to enforce the laws we already have on their platform - laws against voter suppression, against slander and libel and incitement of violence. It worries me a lot. That's why I work with legislators to help pass not just privacy laws, but regulation of big tech. Like banning the negative use cases of algorithms that push up inflammatory content. Because we have to really force people like Mark Zuckerberg to be ethical. They're not going to make that decision themselves.

Do you ever get pushback? People saying, well, who are you to tell us what's ethical now?

I mean, every now and then. But it's never too late to do the right thing. People that have seen the darkest side of this and know how it works are going to be some of our biggest assets in fixing it. As you can see in Congress when people are questioning Mark Zuckerberg [laughs], not everyone has the understanding of these really advanced, cutting-edge technology tools. So I do a lot of briefings for legislators and politicians and testimony and written comment so they understand what they're dealing with. Because this stuff changes and gets more advanced every day, so it's kind of an all-hands-on-deck sort of situation.

We're in an election year now. What do you think the chance is that we're able to have a free and fair democratic election?

This year, it's not going to be great. I think we should actually be kind of scared about what we're going to see.

What's your biggest regret in all this?

Not having blown the whistle before Trump became president.

This interview has been edited and condensed. KK Ottesen's latest book is "Activist: Portraits of Courage."
